Regional Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 41101 
November 2007 
Sustainable Urban Development in Asia
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
CDIA  –  Cities Development Initiative for Asia 
CoP  –  community of practice 
CPS  –  country partnership strategy 
DMC  –  developing member country 
GDP  –  gross domestic product 
MDG  –  Millennium Development Goal 
OD  –  operations department 
RETA  –  regional technical assistance   
RSDD  –  Regional and Sustainable Development Department 
TA  –  technical assistance

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –   General intervention 
Sectors  –   Energy;  transport  and  communications;  water  supply, 
sanitation, and waste management 
Subsectors  –   Energy sector development, multimodal transport and sector

Vice President  U.  Schäfer-Preuss,  Knowledge  Management  and  Sustainable 
  Development 
Acting  Director   
General  X. Yao, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
Director  W.C. Um, Energy, Transport, and Water Division, RSDD 
   
Team leader  M. Lindfield, Principal Urban Development Specialist, RSDD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  2007  technical  assistance  (TA)  program  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development Department (RSDD) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) includes a regional 
technical  assistance  (RETA)  project  to  undertake  analytical  work  on  issues  related  to  the 
management of cities and to support sustainable urban development in Asia.1 Knowledge in this 
area will support the provision of urban infrastructure, which is a high priority under the Medium-
Term Strategy II and an important issue for developing member countries (DMCs). Thus, this 
RETA project responds to both the demands of DMCs and the operational needs of ADB. The 
RETA project's design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES  
2.  Urban economies play a central role in Asia’s economic growth and development. Cities 
and towns are home to a majority of the region’s population and account for most of its gross 
domestic product GDP, job creation, and government revenues. Cities also play host to millions 
of the region’s poor, whose well being and contribution to the economy depend on effective 
urban planning and access to affordable infrastructure services. Well-managed cities act as 
engines of economic growth, bind national economies with the world economy, and become 
symbols of national pride. When conditions in urban areas are poor, cities become bottlenecks to 
growth, hindering regional and global economic integration and frustrating efforts to reduce 
poverty. Many urban areas also play key service-center roles in the national economy and 
support rural poverty reduction. 
3.  Urbanization in Asia is a multifaceted and complex process, the scale of which is striking: 
44 million people are added to city populations every year, equivalent to 120,000 people each 
day. Thus, each day, the construction of more than 20,000 new dwellings, 250 kilometers of new 
roads,  and  additional  infrastructure  to  supply  more  than  6  megaliters  of  potable  water  is 
2
required.  For ADB to be relevant to the needs of its DMCs, it needs to work on operations that 
maximize opportunities for urbanization while also addressing the potential negative impacts of 
urbanization. Institutions that manage urbanization often lack coordination, capacity, and finance. 
Addressing  global  environmental  problems  and  achieving  Millennium  Development  Goals 
(MDGs) is most difficult in Asia’s urban areas. 
4.  Furthermore, the investment needs of Asia’s urban areas are great. The public sector 
cannot meet them alone. A closer partnership between public and private sectors is essential. 
Better engagement with urban sector institutions in both the public and private sectors is a high 
priority. ADB estimates that $60 billion in investment per annum will be needed to meet the 
demand for urban infrastructure services between 2007 and 2010. This includes water supply, 
sanitation, solid waste management, slum upgrading, urban roads, and mass transit systems. 
There is a huge funding gap, and ADB can play a key role in helping to finance this need. In 
addition  to  narrowing  the  funding  gap,  ADB  can  support  the  development  of  critical  urban 
management policies and systems and help DMCs overcome skills shortfalls. 
5.  Concerns about the social and environmental impact of urban development are also 
growing. Under-serviced urban growth often leads to declining environmental quality, congestion, 
and pollution. This is detrimental to the quality of life for residents, even as incomes rise. About 
70% of the world’s poor live in Asia. Urban poverty has reached levels of 60% in some cities, 
and continues to increase, affecting some 800 million people. Nearly one-third of urban poor do 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 26 July 2007. 
2   Kanaley, Trevor, and Brian Roberts, eds. 2006. Urbanization and Sustainability; Case Studies of Good Practices. 
Manila: ADB.

2   
not have access to safe water, and half lack access to adequate sanitation. About the same 
number live in environmentally dangerous areas and/or slums, without any security of tenure. 
High levels of environmental stress compound poverty. The economic impact of pollution in 
Asian urban areas in terms of loss of productivity and health-care costs is estimated to be 
equivalent to 1–5% of GDP. 
6.  ADB's  urban  lending  to  date  amounts  to  more  than  $11  billion,  mostly  focused  on 
infrastructure. Lending has predominantly gone to projects involving water supply and sanitation 
and “multisector” interventions covering sanitation, solid waste, and slum upgrading. The quality 
of ADB’s investments in the urban sector has by and large been rated effective and relevant.3 
The challenge for ADB now is to build on and boost the impact of the individual projects that 
embody  the  principles  set  out  in  the  Urban  Sector  Strategy.4  Upscaling  activities  and/or 
partnering with other agencies are two ways to broaden the impact of such projects. 
7.  In  this  context,  urban  development  is  increasingly  difficult  for  many  governments  to 
manage. In many countries, ADB has had difficulty helping governments improve urban services. 
In addition, there is increasing capacity and willingness on the part of national and local private 
sectors to participate in the delivery of urban services. ADB recognizes these strategic shifts and 
is planning to increase both the quantity and quality of its urban lending by leveraging and 
consolidating cofinancing under longer-term programmatic interventions, bolstering urban sector 
knowledge,  improving  the  quality  of  sector  analysis,  and  supporting  urban  networking  and 
outreach.  ADB’s  urban  action  plan  implemented  through  the  Urban  Community  of  Practice 
(CoP)5 will focus on actions that will mobilize resources and provide the organizational structure 
for this through the proposed Urban Infrastructure Financing Partnership Facility (UIFPF).  
8.  This RETA project will address a number of issues for ADB in this context. The issues 
are: (i) ADB's decreasing ability to respond to some of its clients in the urban sector (given 
strategic shifts, the increasingly prominent role of the private sector, and the need to leverage 
and consolidate cofinancing under longer-term programmatic interventions); (ii) a lack of sector 
depth  and  a  loss  of  ability  to  generate  strategic  sector  analysis  and  diagnostics  in  some 
countries;  and  (iii)  a  lack  of  internal  infrastructure  to  support  networking  among  urban 
professionals and outreach to clients. 
9.  ADB can play a leading role in supporting Asian cities by bolstering urban lending. As a 
financier, ADB can help deliver much-needed investment in infrastructure services, particularly 
through  the  innovation  and  efficiency  initiative6  and  other  approaches.  As  a  development 
institution  with  extensive  experience  in  urban  planning,  infrastructure  services  reform,  and 
poverty reduction, ADB is well placed to deliver knowledge products and finance for sustainable 
and inclusive development of the region’s cities and towns. Additionally, ADB can act as a strong 
partner in policy dialogue, work at multiple levels of government, and foster partnerships with the 
private sector and bilateral donors. 
10.  More analytical work is required to improve ADB’s knowledge of constraints to providing 
urban infrastructure support on a sustainable basis, and of effective approaches to addressing

lending modality constraints on ADB urban operations. 
4  ADB. 2000. Urban Sector Strategy. Manila. Key areas of focus are: (i) maximizing the economic efficiency of urban

3
       
       
those constraints. Furthermore, this work will support ADB’s Urban CoP to move the urban 
sector  agenda  forward  in  operations  departments  (ODs)7.  In  the  context  of  new  financing 
modalities and instruments, this work will also facilitate ADB's efforts to identify new areas of 
operational support and business development. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  ADB’s response to these needs has been to institute a number of activities, including this 
RETA project. Initially, the Managing the Cities in Asia RETA8 project proposed the following 
responses to the issues raised in the Special Evaluation Study on Urban Sector Strategy and 
Operations (footnote 3): (i) more effective support of ADB’s urban operations and the CoP, and 
(ii) more effective partnerships. The present RETA project addresses the former; a subsequent 
RETA9 project will support partnerships. 
12.  The RETA will contribute to the improved management of cities of all sizes in DMCs by 
developing  new  implementation  mechanisms—i.e.,  new  forms  of  project  formulation  and 
administration—and  boosting  support  for  ODs’  urban  sector  operations.  It  will  undertake 
preparatory activities for, and initial implementation activities of, urban sector initiatives that are 
not within ODs normal scope of work. The TA will also improve ADB’s partnership with related 
experts  and  institutions  in  the  region,  and  will  demonstrate  ADB’s  character  as  a  regional 
knowledge organization in the sector. A knowledge management system accessible to both ADB 
staff and external parties will be established to disseminate the RETA project's findings. A 
second RETA project will be formulated to provide further support for ADB’s urban operations 
based on the recommendations of the present RETA. These recommendations will focus on 
improvements in business lines and implementation mechanisms, and include an assessment of 
the need for additional resources to support such improvements. 
13.  The outcomes of the RETA will be: (i) improved operational knowledge and management 
of cities in Asia; and (ii) improved ADB policy dialogue and responsiveness to the demands of 
DMC urban managers. Such knowledge and dialogue will assist ADB in defining the focus areas 
and procedures for operations of the UIFPF. In addition, the RETA will support the CoP in 
strengthening knowledge and management of ADB staff in the sector. 
14.  The main activities of the RETA are: (i) operational support for project and program 
preparation—in particular programs that incorporate important donor partnerships, significant 
public–private partnerships, and/or links to other initiatives such as the carbon market initiative; 
(ii) support for improving ADB’s policy dialogue, relevance to DMCs, and responsiveness to 
DMCs; and (iii) support for the knowledge development and networking activities of the CoP. The 
activities chosen will be selected with a view to: developing  models for improved approaches to 
the implementation of urban projects and the innovation and efficiency initiative; documenting 
important lessons learned (footnote 5); and bolstering sector knowledge in these areas. The 
RETA will also support the coordination of activities with other donors under the UIFPF through 
such mechanisms as Cities Development Initiative for Asia (CDIA). 
 
15.  The TA project will target ODs. It will be demand-driven and supportive of urban sector 
operations, and will seek to enable ODs to effectively and promptly respond to clients’ requests.

8  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance for Managing the Cities in Asia. Manila (TA 6293-REG, approved on 19 
December). 
9  Proposed RETA for the Cities Development Initiative for Asia currently under preparation.

4   
The TA project will aim to minimize application processes both for the proposals processed 
under the RETA, and for the UIFPF. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  The three sets of activities set out in para. 14 above define the three components of the 
RETA set out below. These activities will take place in countries to be selected by ODs.10
17.  Strategic Support for Operations. Under the RETA, RSDD will make a pool of funds 
available and manage the delivery of TA to the ODs in two key areas. 
 
(i)  Sector diagnostics, analysis, and strategies. Formulating Country-Level Sector 
Assessments, Road Maps, and Investment Plans. The CoP will be responsible for 
selecting projects from proposals put forward by ODs. Such activities will also 
determine, based on analysis of operational examples of urban infrastructure 
projects, the most effective ways of delivering such support. 
 
(ii)  Project preparation support: promoting innovation and efficiency.  Expertise 
will be made available to finance specialized consultants to (i) introduce and 
structure private sector participation/public–private partnerships in urban sector 
projects;  (ii)  facilitate  sector-wide  approaches  and  manage  the  required—and 
often extensive—up-front donor coordination (who is doing what, where are the 
gaps, etc.); and (iii) support other innovations (for instance, helping to identify up-
front  financing  gaps  for  the  carbon  market  initiative).  The  RETA  project  will 
examine ways of efficiently leveraging cofinancing for such activities through such 
mechanisms as CDIA.  
18.  Support for Community of Practice: Sharing Sector Knowledge. Beyond the direct 
operational  support  outlined  above,  the  RETA  will  also  support  the  development  and 
dissemination of ADB’s knowledge products. These will be defined by the CoP and will include 
(i) target research to identify new business lines in waste management, urban transport, city 
“clusters” development, and municipal finance; (ii) thematic and technical training and study 
tours for clients and staff (cofinanced, but managed by RSDD, based around a catalogue of 
options,  perhaps  with  private  sector  and/or  commercial  liaison  office  involvement); 
(iii) evaluation, documentation, and monitoring of results and lessons learned from projects, and 
sharing those results with ODs; and (iv) conducting a series of CoP-sponsored seminars (brown 
bags)  where  external  experts  can  share  their  knowledge  with  ADB  urban  staff.    Through 
networking arrangements such as CDIA, and through selected workshops and conferences (not 
necessarily funded under the RETA project), ADB will disseminate its knowledge products and 
expertise in the urban sector. 
19.  Developing  Sector  Expertise.  The  RETA  will  also  support  basic  CoP  operations, 
including  (i)  the  development  and  management  of  the  urban  development  intranet  site 
maintained by RSDD including standard terms of reference (TORs) and identifying consultants; 
and (ii) selected CoP activities, including operations department staff participation at (selected) 
workshops and conferences. 
20.  The long-term outcome will be to increase ADB finance in the urban sector and improve 
knowledge of best practices both for ADB staff and for our DMC clients. The RETA will also 
complement ongoing initiatives, such as the Water Financing Program and Energy Efficiency 
                                                 
10  As yet no countries have been selected for country specific activities, but ADB will obtain government “no-objection” 
prior to undertaking activities in a country.

5
       
       
. This will lead to greater efficiency of urban service delivery. ADB assessments11 
indicate that there is scope to at least double ADB urban sector lending by 2015. It is projected 
that such an increase in investment would lead to improved services for 200 million people—
over half of whom are poor. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
21.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $800,000. The TA project will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The TA cost estimate and financing plan is shown in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  ADB  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  RETA,  with  ADB’s  RSDD  as  the  nodal 
department for its implementation. RSDD will undertake the RETA activities in collaboration with 
other relevant departments. The RETA implementation team will comprise a team leader from 
RSDD and one staff person from each operations department. Implementation will be supported 
by international and national consultants recruited on an individual basis.  
 
23.  Implementing the RETA will require about 20 person-months of international individual 
consultants, including urban and infrastructure experts in energy; transport; water supply and 
sanitation;  environment;  and  municipal  management,  finance  and  urban  economics. 
Implementation  will  also  require  about  50  person-months  of  individual  national  consultants 
support  research  and  data  analysis.  The  consultants  will  undertake  technical  studies  and 
specialized analytical inputs, as required by the priority activities identified by the task force. 
Field studies will be undertaken on a selective basis. Outline TORs are set in Appendix 3. The 
engagement periods of the various consultants will be refined and finalized in response to 
operations department requests, and agreed upon by the task force during implementation of the 
RETA project. The consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
24.  The RETA implementation team will collaborate closely and regularly consult with the 
Urban  CoP.  As  appropriate,  the  team  will  organize  focused  discussions,  workshops,  and 
seminars. The RETA will provide assistance to ODs which is demand-driven, supporting their 
urban operations by providing resources in a highly responsive and timely manner. The RETA 
project will design ways in which such responses can be sustained and piloted in the follow-up 
RETA  project.  The  outputs  of  this  analytical  work  will  be  compiled  as  a  useful  knowledge 
product. The findings of this analytical work will be widely disseminated through publications, 
seminars, workshops, conferences, and other means. ADB staff members will support the TA 
project  as  resource  persons  in  workshops  where  appropriate.  The  RETA  project  will  be 
implemented over 11 months, starting in February 2008 and ending in December 2008. The 
RETA outcome will be evaluated with a view toward contributing to ADB’s policy dialogue with 
DMCs, increasing demand for ADB assistance, and improving the management of cities in 
DMCs in Asia. This evaluation will form the basis of the design of phase II of the RETA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
Sustainable Urban Development in Asia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) project will require inputs from international and national 
consultants drawn from a range of experts, institutions, and organizations. The consultants will 
include urban and infrastructure experts in the areas of planning; energy; transport; water supply 
and sanitation; environment; municipal management; urban finance; and urban economics. The 
national consultants will provide technical and research assistance support for the TA project 
implementation team and should have strong backgrounds and experience in data collection and 
analysis, and practice in the above areas. A small secretariat will manage the TA project and 
respond to requests by the operations departments (ODs)1. Other consultants will be engaged on 
short-term assignments as required by operations departments. The detailed terms of reference for 
the consultants and their engagement periods will be finalized based on requests of operations 
departments in consultation with the managing task force during implementation of the TA project. 
 
B.  Consultants 
 
1.  Urban and Infrastructure Consultants (international, 20 person-months) 
 
2.  The task of the urban and infrastructure consultants will be to: (i) undertake research in the 
areas of waste management, urban transport, cluster development, and municipal finance; and 
(ii) support operations of operations departments and analyze the impact of that support. This 
analysis  will  provide  support  to  the  ADB’s  Urban  Community  of  Practice  (CoP)  and  to  the 
establishment of a partnership facility for the sector which will fund enhanced urban operations. 
They must be capable of designing new modalities of support and innovative solutions, particularly 
in the areas urban finance, energy, transport, water supply and sanitation, environment,  and 
municipal management. This will require knowledge of existing literature and ongoing work within 
and outside the Asian Development Bank (ADB), analysis of trends and issues, identification of 
good practices and innovative approaches, and the ability to make suggestions about how to more 
effective deliver support in the urban sector. The general approach will be to provide consulting 
support  to  the  development  of  sector  strategies  and  projects  as  required  by  operations 
departments, analyze the existing situation of the urban sector in ADB’s DMCs, analyze trends in 
the region, and use the experiences of developing and developed countries to draw lessons for the 
sector. Consultants will be recruited as individual consultants, as set out in ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
2.  Urban and Infrastructure Consultants (national, 50 person-months) 
 
3.  The main task of the national consultants will be to provide high-quality assistance and 
inputs, backed (where needed) by strong data analysis, for the international consultants. The tasks 
of the national consultants will include: supporting the activities of international consultants in the 
field, reviewing documents and literature, collecting data and information, research and analysis 
(both quantitative and qualitative), and preparing notes and briefs. The national consultants will 
provide technical and administrative support to assist the TA implementation team through to the 
completion of the TA project. The national consultants will coordinate with national governments, 
other donors, and other ADB projects as needed. National consultants supporting the core team 
will also assist with developing and administering the urban website, including dissemination of 
materials, press releases, speeches, questions and answers, key messages, slide presentations; 
conversion of desktop files to .pdf and .html format, consistent with ADB website guidelines; and
